Imagine...  You are driving in a car. You can't stop. But a part breaks... a tire goes flat. You need to fix and replace this tire as you go. Then another breaks. You replace it. You keep driving. The windshield wears down and breaks. You replace it. And after a while... every single part of the car breaks and is replaced over time. Eventually, you are still driving the same car, but every part is different. There are no parts left over from the original car you left in.         THAT is Mythology. TRUE STORIES that have been changed little by little, till the original story is lost. Everyone thinks these stories are made up, but they weren't in the beginning. These historical events are so old, so many details changed or forgotten, that no one alive today remembers the truth.

Just in case people were wondering, this is what the writing is on the little 'thought bubble' intro:

Egypt
- The Egyptian Creation myth of the world rising out of water is a common motif associated with chaos in contrast to “order” that is the universe.
- The legend of Osiris, Isi and Horus was the most popular and influential myth in ancient Egyptian mythology.
- Thoth is the Egyptian god of communication and knowledge. He’s depicted with an ibis head, holding a scroll and pen reed.
- Egyptian mythology is among the oldest in recorded history!
- Ma’at is the goddess of morality, justice, law and divine order. Her feather determined if people got into the afterlife peacefully.

Greek
- Mount Olympus is where the Olympian Gods reside. It was created after the _Titanomachy_, the great battle between the Olympians and the Titans.
- Athena is responsible for turning Medusa’s hair into serpents! Medusa was always a gorgon in Greek mythology, but the origin story didn’t appear until Metamorphoses by Roman poet Ovid.
- Persephone’s descent into the underworld and reunion with her mom Demeter is the origin story of the seasons.
- The capture of Artemis’ sacred Ceryneian Hind was one of the twelve labours of Heracles.
- Artemis and Apollo are two of Zeus’ many, many, many, many children.

Indian
- The Ramayana is considered the adi-kavya (first poem) in Hindu mythology and is the largest ancient epic in world literature!
- Rakshasas are described as deadly blood-drinking creatures, they convey several similarities to vampires in Western mythology.
- The hero of this epic, _Rama_, is the seventh avatar of god Vishnu.
- Sita is the daughter on Mother Earth and the avatar of goddess Laksmi, Vishnu’s wife.
- Hanuman is a die-hard devotee of Rama. He leads an army of Vanaras (aka monkeys) into battle against the Rakshasas in order to save Sita.

Norse
- In Norse mythology, Ragnorak is the pre-destined series of events, from natural disasters to the infamous battle between major Gods resulting in the apocalypse.
- Ragnorak was not the ultimate end of the universe! After the earth was consumed in flames and submerged in water, a fresh, new earth was destined to resurface, even better than before!
- Thor’s hammer, Mjönir, symbolizes creative and destructive power.
- The cosmology of Norse mythology has nine realms which are unified by the Yggdrasil tree.
- When Heimdell sounds his trumpet, Gjallarhorn_, it will signify the beginning of _Ragnorak and can be heard across all nine realms!

I know this is only the intro, but I really want to see the source for this version of the story of Persephone. I've never heard of Kore changing her name to Persephone, just that the myths of Kore and Persephone are generally taken to be the same myth under different names. Although I studied classical Greek and Latin (and, of course, the myth-heavy literature in those languages) in college, I haven't done much with it since then, so it's not only possible but likely that I've missed something, and this one sounds like something I want to read.

(Granted, in literary terms, the name of Kore probably did change to Persephone, since Kore is probably the older version, given that 1) κόρη means "girl," and the earliest myths tend to use descriptions as names (see also the Hebrew account of the first man, Adam, which is Hebrew for "earth," which is what God made him from, and his wife, Eve, or "rib"), and 2) the Thesmophorian mystery cult referred to her as Kore, and that cult predated writing in Athens.)

I find the idea of Myths being the theories for the natural state of the world, in a kind of primitive version of Science, fascinating as a fan of Mage: The Ascension. In that tabletop RPG, Reality is fluid and dependent on belief, shifting to accommodate the changes in human thought. From that perspective, then, the myth that explains the changing seasons as being a result of Demeter missing her daughter while she's down in the underworld is as valid a theoretical model as the one that chalks the seasons up to the tilt of the planet in relation to the sun.

MtAs asks the players and storytellers to imagine a world where all theories could be true. And then it creates its in-universe conflict, over different groups and individuals trying to impose their ideas of Reality on everyone else. Because the more people believe in something, the more true it gets.

MtAs is also a game about wizards, super martial artists, reality hackers, and miracle workers getting into fights with Men In Black and Terminators. It is a game about beautiful, insane ideas, and I love it very much.

Greetings all. All mythology is anchored in prejudice. Prejudice means a person can’t stop believing something. They typically pick these beliefs up during childhood, when they are just starting to form their own minds. Kids sometimes get their prejudice from the people they grow up with, and sometimes they come to the wrong idea about the world all by themselves.

All prejudiced people see their own prejudice as an absolute truth of the universe (aka a delusion). They frequently build an alternate perceptual world trying to explain their own prejudice(s). If they write down a description of their world, you get doctrine. Most doctrines are prejudiced manifestos. Doctrines are the conceptual cores of all mythologies (used as a reference).

Having a prejudice is not the same as having a belief. A prejudice always exists at 100% confidence, and can’t be switched off. So the person is evidence-immune on the prejudiced belief. Each concept a person learns needs to be carefully explained using their own prejudices. That’s because people use their prejudices as trusted mental anchors for everything in their own minds. By the time people die, they are talking about how their prejudice anchors the entire universe. They believe that because they painstakingly put their own prejudice there.

Prejudice is not only the basis of mythology, most personality faults are learned mind faults (like the “I don’t trust people” prejudice of paranoia), or a racial prejudice (“x group is bad” prejudice of racism). Whenever people are talking about extreme belief, or faith, they really mean the person is prejudiced, and can’t change their mind no matter what shows up.

OK, so one problematic liberty I wanna point out. The Demeter Persephone story is not actually intended to talk about winter, that's sort of our interpretation of it, and potentially that of the Romans (they didn't much care for winter given their war schedule so maybe Ceres mourns over winter). For the Greeks though, winter was growing season, and it was too hot in the summer for the crops to thrive, so for the ancient Greeks Demeter's disappearance was discussing the summer. I know that's kind of nitpicky, and the spirit of the myth is to describe the "we're not farming" season, which would be winter in a whole heck of a lot of places, but I think the specifics are important for providing context for the myth, because ultimately myths were how the Greeks conceived of their universe.

You were right on myths until the American dream thing. While a myth itself holds more falsehood and beliefs, an American Dream story is much more 'mythic'. I use this term loosely, but the word 'myth' bears a connotation of falseness and being wrong. Something 'mythic' is relating to or resembling a myth. Success stories fit this definition as mythic, because they resemble something that SEEMS (keyword here) impossible, but isn't. An actual myth however IS impossible by definition, and portrays levels of easily debatable falsehood.

I do look forward to the rest of Crash Course Mythology though. Keep up the good work!

I am a student of contemporary religion and I'm looking forward for this series! Little clarification however (6:08): The main point of emphasis for the study of contemporary religion/religious studies is purely anthropological, we do not try to comprehend supernatural or place god everywhere (theology...), we try to study the reasons why and how humans shape and understand their culture through religion and through myths. In myths, the main agents don't need to be supernatural, it is just the perceived context in myths that matters, i.e. how is this event explained, why there are these kinds of rules/morals etc. They often involve gods, but they are not necessary components.

We read the Hymn to Demeter in a greek studies class in College; our professor interpreted the season during which nothing grows because Persephone is in the Underworld as summer rather than winter. Her basis was that based on Greece's climate, winters would be rather mild, while summers would scorch the earth, wilting and dehydrating all of the crops.
Also, my favorite part of the story always gets left out, when Demeter gives up on finding Kore and instead tries to replace her. She disguises herself as an old woman, and gets hired as a wet nurse for a rich family with a baby. Her plan is to galvanize this baby into a new supergod child for herself by heating him with godly flames. The mother catches her at this and is understandably upset. Demeter then reveals herself and resumes her search for Kore.

Man I'm hyped for this series.  I freaking love mythology.  When I was a kid I got super into myths and my grandmother used to sit and listen to me retell them.  Throughout my childhood I would learn new myths so that I had new ones to tell her.  In my adult years her memory started to slip and when I would visit her she would want to hear them again and I could tell she didn't remember and it was like hearing them for the first time.  When she died we could tell it was her last day so my siblings and I were called together and we each visited her and spent some time alone with her saying goodbye.  She could no longer speak and I'll never know if she could understand what was going on but in addition to saying goodbye I spent that time telling her a myth I'd told her many times before and at her funeral I told a myth and explained the role they played in our relationship.  In short, myths mean so much to me and I'm very excited to watch this crash course on them and maybe even learn some new ones.

Well, I'm missing an important statement in the video, and it's about how a myth can start. How can anyone tell such a strange story for the first time and be believed.

First, most written myths were, well, written when they were already known. Very few people knew how to write or read in the ancient times, so they tell the stories. And in that tellling the story can be modified. The more significant the story is, the more times is going to be telled and the more modifications is going to get. Also, there's a cultural difference, since the XIX century and the scientific method, we care a lot about precision when telling a story. Because precision is what gives that newly invented thing, science, all it's magic. However, that's recent, back then people didn't care if the storyteller has made up some details.

Those both voluntary and involuntary modifications stack up, and can turn the story into a completely different one.

I am very pleased that you mentioned that myths have been told and interpreted in many different ways. Such as the story of Persephone that you told. I grew up being told that Hades (Deity) made a deal with Persephone, if she could walk out of Hades (Realm) only looking forward, never looking back, she may leave. If she does look back, she must stay. She made it all the way to the exit, but with one foot out of Hades (Realm) and the other foot still in, she heard a sound behind her and got startled and looked back. Hades (Deity) and Demeter argued if she can return to Demeter had to stay with Hades (Deity/Realm). Zeus decreed since Persephone was half in and half out of Hades (Realm) than she would stay in Hades (Realm) for half of the year and can leave the other half. For the most part, in these myths, the ideas of the story are the same, but the details are different.

James Kirk and Gandalf the Great are myth too. Power Rangers and TMNT are just as mythical as the rest of modern fiction too. I think you get the point.

Just my own two cents, myth isn't "primitive" science.
There are definitely some aspects of myth as science in explaining things, but I would argue that science/technology are related to humans ability to act to change their worlds, myths don't really provide that beyond a few about who you could sacrifice/pray/give respect/etc to.
Instead I would argue that myth is more about worldview, helping people reconcile the world with their worldview. Social societies have very social myths, violent ones violent ones, bureaucratic bureaucratic, etc, and the distinctions between Hercules and harry potter isn't that we used to think Hercules could be used to plow irrigation for us, but Hercules was a story used to extol the virtues of that culture, like harry potter is today.

Greek major here.  In ancient Greek, the underworld is sometimes referred to by the genitive form of Hades' name (Greek nouns use a case system), which can mean "the house of Hades."  It is never referred to by the nominative form, so to ancient readers, the god vs place confusion didn't exist.  The genitive case is kinda of like the preposition "chez" in French.
